Sir:

While on an inspection trip to the McIntosh Indian Residential school last week, the Principal informed me that they are having trouble with the water pipe between the school and the barn, as it was continually freezing. He informed me that if we would supply the material, lumber $35.00 and piping $25.00, that the school would be responsible for making the box and protecting same; and in the spring they would bury the pipes so as to experience no further trouble.

Therefore I informed him that he could order this material, at a cost not exceeding $60.00, as I felt sure that you would authorize this most necessary expenditure. I would be glad to receive the necessary authority for my files.

The school authorities also asked for two knock-down cupboards for the playroom and the sewing rooms. I will obtain prices on these and submit same for your consideration.

The Principal showed me Dept. letter 130-7-9, of October 5th last, re. appropriation of $2000.00 for digging the culvert under the C.N.Ry. The Principal informs me that he gave the Father Provincial, in October or November, 1927, a copy of a contract which had been given him by Mr. Fred McIntosh, who was the Divisional Engineer on that section of the railroad, and in which it was stated that the Railway authorities would see to it that the water in the culvert would be at least 4 feet deep. I would suggest, therefore, that you ascertain if this work should not be done by the Railway, without any charge to our Department. It would be cheaper and better to have the work done before the ice goes out in March, instead of in June. There is only 12 inches of water in the culvert at the present time.

Your obedient servant,

Frank Edwards
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir,

I visited the McIntosh Residential School last week. The Principal wishes to know if he can purchase anew dynamo, 10 H.P., for the power house as the small one now in use is too heavily loaded. The small one could be used for sawing wood, etc.

He also requests refills for five Foamide Fire Extinguishers.

Bookcase for the school room (cost about $25.00)
Four (4) dear springs
New plow - cost about $20.00 and repairs to old one.
Bread slices and potato peeler
3 gals. Turpentine
15 " White flat wall paint,
10 " boiled linseed oil,
10 " Floor Varnish,
2 " White Enamel,
25 lbs. black lead.
Also burlap for the passages and smoke room, including glue and strips. The School authorities to be responsible for the work.

1000 ft. lumber, planed two sides for partitions - cost about $45.
An amount for clearing and brushing land.

The Principal informs me that nothing has been done as regards deepening the culvert under the C.N. Railway. It will only be possible to get through with a small boat unless this is done and he has over 1000 logs he wishes to get through and has to use the large boat for bringing the supplies from the station to the school.

There is also a large hole in the concrete dam which should be attended to while the water is low. This has been reported before.
Sir:

I have your letter of the 30th instant, with reference to improvements at the Maltese Indian Residential School. I am pleased to inform you that the O. R. has been requested to prepare a channel under the railway culvert, 4 ft. deep by 10 ft. wide. I expect this work will be attended to without delay. The request for a new system is being given consideration at the present time and you will be further advised. The refills for the fire extinguishers are being ordered by the Department and will be sent direct to the school.

You may expend $20 in the purchase of a new plough and you may supply for the use of the school the turpentine, paint, oil, varnish, enamel and black lead requested by the Rev. Principal. You might get an estimate of the cost of supplying burlap for the corridors. You may purchase 1,000 ft. of lumber, at an estimated cost of $45. The question of filling in the hole in the concrete dam is receiving the attention of the departmental engineer and you will be further advised. A separate communication will be addressed to you regarding extra land, which has been requested for the use of the school.

With reference to the Principal's request concerning the Department's proposals for improvements at the Maltese School this year, I have to say that there are no funds for the purpose of an addition. $500.00 is available for purchasing land and $400 for painting the main building. Funds were also provided for the channel under the culvert. There has been some correspondence regarding a frigidaire, a small mangle and a boat house; but these improvements will have to stand until the cost of the other work has been determined.

I am enclosing an extra copy of this letter, which you may forward to the Rev. Principal for his information.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Dear Sir:

Referring to your letter July 26 # 108-20, I beg to inform you that from the three items mentioned in your letter: frigidaire, boat house and mangle, two are absolutely necessary, frigidaire and boat house. The coat for the first one as you were informed by Brother Eugen will be around $1600.00; the boat house will cost about $800.00.

I will be very disappointed if at least those two items are not granted this year. I am asking them since four years and they always replied that they have no funds for that. Besides that Mr. Ferrier told Rev. Father Magnan, our provincial at St.-Boniface that all my requests were granted.

As for the mangle, it will be very useful and helpful for the Sisters, but as there is no funds again I could wait till next year.

As for the Culvert nothing has been done yet and now it is quite nearly impossible to go to the Station even with a light boat on account of the low water which is decreased all the time.

As for painting, the work will be finish in two or three weeks, but the amount granted for that was quite half enough. To have the work done 1st class as the Department asked, we needed more than $600.00. I notified already the Dept. about that but did not receive any reply. I did not stop the work, thinking that the Dept. will agree to pay all these expenses.

Hoping that my request will be granted

I remain, Sincerely Yours

Ottawa, August 21, 1929.

Sir:

I have your L06-20 of the 15th instant, with reference to a frigidaire, a boat house and a small mangle for the McIntosh Indian Residential School. I am pleased to inform you that funds can be found for the construction of a boat house, at an estimated cost of not more than $300. If this entire amount is not required for the purpose, you will please effect the resultant saving. The work should be done by day labour, under the supervision of the Rev. Principal. He should requisition to you for the materials required, if he is unable to purchase them to advantage locally.

I regret there are no funds for a frigidaire for this school. There is some question concerning the amount of power that we are developing there, and it is possible that there may be some change made. The matter of a frigidaire will have to stand for the time being. If a small mangle is required in the laundry this year, the school authorities will have to purchase it themselves.

I note by the Principal's letter that he is enquiring regarding the additional amount for painting. In this connection, I may say that he was written on August 8th, authorizing an additional $500.

Your obedient servant,

Frank Edwards, Esq.,

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,

Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

The Principal of the McIntosh Indian Residential School wishes me to ask for a cheque for $500 so as to enable him to clear more land at the school and to give employment to Indians before the rat season opens. The Indians in that neighborhood are very badly off and there is practically no trapping, most of the fur having been trapped out. They also wish for an amount of $500 for a chicken house for about 200 fowl. He also states that a drying tumbler is needed in the worst way.

I have informed him I would bring these matters to the attention of the Department but make no recommendation as I understand most of our school funds have been expended. I took upon myself the responsibility for authorizing an extra room being made in the school for one of the Sisters, the cost not to exceed $30. Also a door being made from the bedroom to the bathroom at a cost not to exceed $15, as these were very important for the convenience in taking care of sick. He also asks for an extra $50 for moving the bath and making a few extra changes in the bathroom for the convenience of sick patients. He wishes too, extrashfts, pulleys and belting for the laundry at a cost of $25.

He informs me the hole in the dam at the school which I understand was to be repaired by the Greater Winnipeg Water District last Fall has not yet been attended to. I shall be glad if you will take this matter up with them as the work should not be delayed too long owing to the high water in the Spring enlarging the hole.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, February 5, 1930.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, relative to certain requests of the Principal of the McIntosh Indian Residential School.

Regarding the providing of an amount of $500 for the erection of a chicken house, I have to say that funds for this purpose will be available in our appropriation for the next fiscal year. In the meantime, however, you should obtain from the Principal a report as to the size and kind of chicken house required and how he would propose to have it erected. The building be undertaken, carried out by the school authorities - including the purchase and supplying of the materials required?

I request the request to be supplied with a statement to say that the department has no objection to this purpose.

I also approve of the authority given to make for one of the Sisters a partition between the bedroom to the bathroom.

I also approve of an expenditure of $25 for the purpose of moving the bath and fitting the bathroom for the convenience of the laundry. This should only be forwarded when funds become available.

McIntosh Ont May 13th. 1930

Mr. Russell T. Fennell
Supt. of Ind. Education

Dear Sir:

We have made several attempts to obtain from the Department three items of which we are in great need. They were promised at a certain time but have been left aside since then.

For the welfare of the children we have asked a Tumbler for the laundry. As we have explained before the present drying room is treacherously dangerous for the children's health, on account of the excessive dampness which is in the apartment when drying the clothes. At all cost this mode of drying clothes should be changed and the only way favorable should be to install a Tumbler, this we could do our share by setting it place through Brother Gauthier's ability.

Next we wanted an electric mangle. We were promised one sometimes ago but as the Department had no funds we were left waiting. I would be very grateful, if after waiting so patiently it was granted to me this time. After looking several types of mangle, I found the one enclosed, the 56 Institutional Type to answer to our needs, unless the Department knows of a better one than this. I leave this all to your care.

Then comes the question of a "Frigidaire". It was proposed one of $800.00 but as I have explained to Mr. Edwards last fall that the one at Kenora's Catholic School is not satisfactory. We have examined that of the other School at Kenora and I think one of the same type would give complete satisfaction. As long as we are to have a frigidaire we wish for a good one.

Trusting that our demands be favorably heard and granted through your kindness,

I remain,

Yours very truly

[Signature]

Principal
Ottawa, May 20, 1930.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 13th instant, with reference to a drying tumbler, an electric mangle and a frigidaire for the McIntosh Indian Residential School. I regret that there are but limited funds for improvements of this kind at your school this year. On February 5th, I wrote Mr. Indian Agent Edwards with reference to a henhouse. Perhaps you would prefer to have a drying tumbler and an electric mangle and have the henhouse stand until another year. Please write to Mr. Edwards without delay in this connection, so that the most urgent improvement can be arranged.

I regret that consideration to the supplying of a frigidaire cannot be given this year. Funds are not available for the purpose and, in the second place, we have not yet made the final arrangements in connection with the power that is to be developed at the McIntosh School.

Your obedient servant,

A. S. Williams,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. C. Perreault, C. M. I.,
Principal,

It is therefore natural that the attention of equipment manufacturers and laundry engineers has been concentrated upon the technical phases of the business. As a result of this extensive research, there have been great forward steps in every department of the laundry. The devices which served a useful purpose in the old-fashioned plant have become as obsolete as the words which described them. Even the word "laundryman" with reference to laundryowners, and the term "mangler" as a name for flat work ironers, have passed out of the industry's vocabulary.

Vorclone equipment has played an important part in this transition from the crude devices of early days to the smooth-running, efficient, scientific, mechanical operations of the present. From an engineering standpoint, Vorclone machines are the climax of an evolution which began years ago when laundry equipment was in its rudimentary state.

It is not so long ago the clothes were wrung out by hand or in power wringers and dried in the open air. Then came the early extractors, crude adaptations of the basket centrifugals first used for spinning molasses from sugar and the era of the dry room. Now 75 per cent extraction has reached a high point of efficiency with the use of high speed extractors. Drying tumblers, too, have progressed far beyond the high temperature methods of the past to the new standards set by tumblers operating at low temperatures.

Today the industry is well on the road toward new and greater development—the merchandising of its perfected service is being accomplished through widespread effort and publicity. Laundryowners realize that they
cannot reap the benefit of their years of expensive technical improvement unless they tell their customers about it. And they are constantly alert to the new opportunities for educating the public to the value of what has already been accomplished. The next logical step in the growth of the industry is the constant effort to better the quality of work through adequate and efficient equipment. The most forceful advertisement of all is the satisfied customer, and only work of the highest quality can create this type of client.

Here, at this point in the laundry business—the getting of new customers and the retention of old friends—Vorclone equipment plays a vital part. Principles and Advantages of the

WITH all its mechanical refinements the Vorclone is not merely an "Improved" tumbler. It goes right to the heart of the drying problem with a new basic principle—the Vorclone Dry-by-Air method.

The Vorclone drying tumbler was designed for two definite purposes: To approximate as closely as possible the conditions and results of natural drying in the open air, and to set new standards of speed and economy in the drying operation. Both of these results have been accomplished, and today the Vorclone tumbler has revolutionized drying practice.

No other drying tumbler can equal Vorclone drying speed when operating at the same low temperature, because the Vorclone is the only tumbler operating on the Vacuum principle. This is best proven by the fact that even on most efficient types of "Hot Blast" tumblers the replacement of the fan with a Vorclone Patented Suction Device increases the drying speed from 25 to 40% and reduces the temperature to as low as 150 degrees Fahrenheit. This proves that the Vorclone Principle of absorbing moisture is more practical than the old fashioned evaporation process and high temperature.

What Is the Vorclone Principle?

In the Vorclone Dry-by-Air Process, immense quantities of mild, warm air replace the confined, intensely heated air of high temperature drying methods. Because of this tremendous volume of fresh air, Vorclone dries rapidly and perfectly at a temperature of approximately 125 degrees.

This remarkable achievement is made possible by the Vorclone Suction Device, a patented feature which cannot be duplicated. This amazing invention, many times as powerful as an ordinary centrifugal fan of the same size, is built into the machine at the lower right or left end. When the fan motor is started, the action of the Suction Device immediately creates a "Vorclone" (miniature cyclone), with a whirling motion which draws all air from the drum and creates a powerful vacuum. The vacuum in the drum instantly sucks enormous volumes of pure, clean, fresh air (room temperature) through the inlets at the top of the machine. Here the air passes through a series of coils and is warmed to a temperature of 125 degrees. Perfectly dry, it enters the drum, and, completely permeating the clothes, it absorbs moisture to its full capacity. Laden with moisture and lint, it is then drawn in swirling currents in its downward course into the trough at the bottom of the machine and through the suction outlet from which it is discharged outside of the building.
Quality, Odorless Drying

The Vorclone suction principle of drying at low temperature is a direct opposite of the evaporation process, which depends on blasts of hot air to vaporize the moisture content of its load. The downward course of air travel assists the drop of clothes which loosens the free moisture content, permitting the air to attain its fullest efficiency. The downward course is the natural gravitation of all articles heavier than air. Only extremely hot air and steam vapors rise, but hot air above a temperature of approximately 160 degrees decomposes animal fats, causing a bad odor. Animal fat is the base of laundry soap and almost impossible to eliminate entirely in the rinsing process.

No other method can even approximate the results obtained with the Vorclone, because rapid, perfect drying cannot be done at a low temperature without the immense volume of air drawn through the clothes by the Vorclone Suction Device, provided exclusively with the Vorclone tumbler.

Rapid Drying Plus Economy

The Vorclone drying tumbler produces a direct and immediate improvement in the operating cost of laundries. It saves time, labor and money. One important factor in these savings is the speed with which Vorclone dries clothes. The operating tests on page eight show the average results obtained. It is the universal experience of Vorclone users that Vorclone speeds up the drying operation and handles more pounds of clothes per day. There is a further increase in capacity, due to the fact that work of all kinds can be dried in the Vorclone at one time without the slightest sacrifice in quality. That means maximum output for every dollar invested in drying equipment. For example, a 5-pocket machine with a load of 30 lbs. in each pocket will dry in from 20 to 25 minutes, depending upon extraction.

The steam consumption of the Vorclone tumbler is surprisingly low. Some plants estimate that the Vorclone uses about one-third less steam than other types.

No Lint Accumulation

Another important saving results from the continuous discharge of lint outside of the building. There is no lint accumulation on the coils or about the machine, and there are no lint screens to clean. This one item alone represents hundreds of hours of labor in the course of a year.

Clothes dried in the Vorclone are just warm. There are no clouds of steam or lint blown out into the room when doors are opened. No time is lost in waiting for the clothes to cool, and no blast of cold air is necessary. The operator opens the cylinder immediately after drying is completed, and handles the clothes comfortably without gloves.

The machine itself is compact and carefully constructed for long, uninter-
rupted service. In actual performance, Vorclone has a remarkable record for the elimination of repair charges and costly shutdowns.

Every analysis of actual drying costs shows that the Vorclone tumbler dries clothes at less than a quarter of a cent per pound.

**Dries Light and Heavy Materials in One Load**

Because of its low operating temperature and steady flow of fresh air, the Vorclone tumbler handles all classes of work at the same time. The materials in one bundle may include everything from heavy woolens to filmy laces, with perfect assurance of quality results without danger of overdrying.

**Better Working Conditions**

The Vorclone Dry-by-Air Process also has an important effect upon the efficiency of laundry workers. It is not only simple, understandable, and free from operating troubles, but it creates more pleasant working conditions.

It prevents the air in the room from becoming heavy, foul, and unhealthy due to lack of ventilation and the presence of lint, moisture, and foreign matter. The air is kept clean and pure at all times, with no overheating in summer.

**No Unpleasant Odor**

With a maximum drying temperature of 125 degrees and the continuous discharge of lint, Vorclone air-dried clothes never have the stuffy, unpleasant odor which results from drying at high temperatures. The moment the housewife opens a bundle of laundry work, she notices the difference. The clothes have a freshness and fragrance heretofore obtainable only by drying outdoors in a stiff breeze.

**Ideal for Blanket Drying**

Because of the small margin between the drying temperature of 125 degrees and a normal room temperature, woolens can be dried in the Vorclone along with other work without the slightest danger of shrinkage. Blankets come out fresh, fluffy, and with the nap raised.

**No Scorching or Discoloration**

Scorching or discoloration is impossible when clothes are dried in the Vorclone at 125 degrees. Housewives appreciate having their linens come back from the laundry snowy white. No artificial method ever devised can duplicate the bleaching ability and purifying potency of the oxygen in the air.

The drying temperature not only determines the quality of every piece that is laundered and dried in a power laundry, but it has a far-reaching effect on the life of the clothes.

**Easy on Clothes**

At the Vorclone temperature of 125 degrees, the finest fabrics can be handled without injury. 180 degrees is
the deterioration point. Above this point, the heat of the drying process bakes out the natural oils which give life to the fibres of cottons, woolens, and various other materials.

This accounts for the familiar saying of the housewife, "The laundry wears out my clothes too soon." It is a well-known fact that clothes are not worn out by washing in a power laundry, because modern processes cause less wear and tear than rubbing clean on the old-fashioned wash-board. It is the excessive heat in drying that takes the life out of clothes.

Drying at 240 degrees is dangerous. Subjecting a load of freshly washed garments to this temperature for a period of 25 to 40 minutes has a direct bearing on the general quality of the finished bundle. The clothes are harsh and stiff, yellowed from overheating, and sometimes scorched. A more disagreeable result is the foul odor due to scorching of the fine fuzzy fibres and baking them into the clothes. Worse still is the hidden damage which has destroyed the very life of the fibrous structure in every garment.

A Drying Temperature Below the Danger Line

Such ruinous results are impossible with Vorclone Drying at 125 degrees. If the clothes should accidentally be tumbled all day, there would be no trace of deterioration.

This feature makes the Vorclone Dry-by-Air Process one of the most important accomplishments in years in the field of laundry engineering. With its remarkable combination of low temperature and fresh air, at an actual reduction in drying time and drying cost, it has removed one of the greatest obstacles in the path of future development in the industry and laid the foundation for a tremendous growth.

Hundreds of laundry owners have already seen its advantages from this standpoint. Some have not stopped with pocketing the savings which result from drying with Vorclone. They have begun to tell their customers about it, merchandising Vorclone air-dried clothes as an important part of their service.

Vorclone Builds Future Business

Between the laundry owner and a vast new field of potential business has stood the old-time prejudice of many housewives against power laundries. The big outstanding service of Vorclone to the laundry industry is its part of overcoming that prejudice and making power laundry work popular.

The Vorclone Suction Device Explained

This patented fan is one of the outstanding Vorclone features of construction. The Vorclone Suction Device produces a suction so powerful that lint screens are entirely eliminated. It moves a much greater volume of air than any other type of fan and its efficiency is not impaired when discharging against a colder outside temperature.

The separate motor on the Suction Device is an important factor in the high efficiency of the Vorclone drying tumbler. It not only eliminates additional belt drives, with their attendant troubles, but it maintains the whirling action of the air at a constant speed.

The best of materials and workmanship are built into this vital part of the Vorclone tumbler. The fan blades, made of sheet steel, are sturdy and durable. Free, easy action at all times is assured by the self-aligning ball bearings.

The Suction Device stand is cast iron. Combined with the stand is the outlet, which is made of steel, accurately tested, specially shaped, and multiple riveted.

All lint, dirt, and moisture sucked down by the Vorclone Suction Device is discharged through this outlet and deposited outside of the building.

Analysis of the Vorclone Suction Device in actual operation shows four outstanding characteristics:

1. Discharging against a colder outside temperature does not affect the volume of hot air displaced.
2. There is positive suction through the entire length of its air force. The suction is just as powerful up in the drum as it is at the mouth of the Suction Device.
3. Suspended in its whirling air currents, dirt, lint, and foreign matter are collected and held until discharged. This assures cleanliness in the machine. Definitely eliminates the possibility of unpleasant odors and unclean appearance. No clogging. No explosions due to lint accumulation.
4. The Vorclone Suction Device is not limited to operate at a certain speed as is the case with centrifugal fans, which if speeded up above a predetermined speed lose their ability to displace an additional volume of air.

It would be possible to operate the Vorclone tumbler with a much smaller Vorclone Suction Device at a higher speed. However, a larger fan at lower speed is used because it radically reduces wear on bearings and other parts.

Actual tests prove that the Vorclone Suction Device will circulate or displace more cubic feet of air per minute than a number of ordinary fans of equal size.
Cylinder Construction

The cylinder can be divided into individual compartments, reached through sliding doors. Each cylinder is specially built and can be furnished with any number of pockets, as long as the minimum width of each pocket is 15 inches.

The 46 x 120 and 42 x 120 cylinders are available from one to eight pockets. The 42 x 90 cylinder can be divided into six pockets. The 42 x 60 cylinder can be supplied with as many as four pockets, and the 42 x 40 cylinder is available in one or two pockets. The Junior can be had in two pockets.

Cylinder partitions are made of high quality, three mesh to the inch, galvanized after woven wire screen, to permit the circulation of air currents throughout the tumbler. This gives a distinct advantage over solid partitions. The tumbling bars themselves are made of smooth, heavily galvanized iron, rigid in construction and incapable of damaging clothes or ripping off buttons, as is often the case with cast iron bars.

Sliding doors are built in sections—easily operated and perfectly fitted. The improved sliding doors are developed to a considerable degree, lightweight sheet steel with perforated embossing, reinforced on top and bottom. The end runners are constructed of cold-rolled steel, case-hardened to provide long life. The door retainer strips are machine formed and welded into one piece. The slides are interchangeable and can be taken off by removing a few bolts.

The Vorclone drying tumbler is a dependable piece of equipment. It combines the distinctive features of the Dry-by-Air Process with a construction which is simple, understandable, and mechanically sound.

Carefully selected materials are built into the machine with painstaking care. Motors, bearings and other accessories conform to high engineering standards. Every possible effort has been made to insure continuous, uninterrupted operation and maximum life for the tumbler.

The remarkable record of the Vorclone tumbler in actual laundry service is a logical result of this policy.
Safety Drum Locking Device and Locater

This perfected safety device was developed by Vorclone engineers to guarantee absolute protection to the operator when loading or unloading the tumbler. It locks the drum securely in any position. It prevents the cylinder from starting and injuring the operator if the belt is thrown accidently onto the driving pulley.

The sliding door latch is an added provision for the convenience and safety of the operator. He is protected by a self-locking mechanism, which locks the compartments instantly and automatically when the drier is open or closed, and prevents the constant motion of the machine from opening them.

Double End Drive

All tumblers with a cylinder length more than 60 inches are double end driven. This eliminates any possibility of cylinder twisting out of shape, a common fault with older types of tumblers.

Silent Chain Drive for Cylinder

All motor-driven machines are regularly equipped with a silent chain drive running in a bath of oil. The oil is retained in a leak-proof cast iron case. The chain, of standard make, is very durable and with ordinary attention will last throughout the life of the machine. This method eliminates grinding noises and the clattering of gears. The silent chain drive is standard on all machines having motor drives.

Perfect Balance with Ball and Roller Bearings

Particular consideration was necessary in the selection of the ball and roller bearings, to insure uninterrupted service of the driving mechanism.

Oversize, self-aligning ball bearings are installed on the main trunnion shaft, and roller bearings of standard make on all driving mechanism. This assures easy, frictionless action at all times. The maximum load on the bearings is never more than 30% of their rating. With ordinary care they will function perfectly during the entire life of the machine.

The bearing equipment of the Vorclone drying tumbler greatly reduces the consumption of power and maintains an accurate balance which aids in producing smooth, continuous operation.

Aspirator and Steam Pressure Control

The Aspirator performs a definite function. It draws off the condensate from each of the three coil sections and maintains an even steam pressure at all times. Unless the condensate is properly disposed of, it seriously hampers the efficiency of the tumbler.
The powerful action of the patented Vorclone suction device creates a vacuum in the cylinder. This Vacuum suction force draws air into the cylinder through openings above coil compartments located directly above cylinder. None of the air is ever recirculated; all of it, together with lint and foreign matter is discharged continuously to the outside. There are no lint screens or traps to clean, no lint accumulation in any part of machine. The high velocity of air travel always keeps machine free from lint and foreign matter, always in shape for maximum production.

With respect to the Indian Residential School, R. G., at McIntosh, I made an inspection here some time ago and found that while all other conditions at the school are exceptionally good, that a similar condition with respect to sewage disposal exists at this school as at Pelican.

The septic tank effluent is passed into the lake without preliminary treatment of any description. I wish to make it perfectly clear that ordinary treatment by sedimentation in a septic tank only removes 25 to 75% of the bacteria present in the sewage. Where, however, the septic tank is combined with either broad irrigation filters or contact beds, the percentage removal of bacteria is increased 10 to 15%.

MR. INDIAN AGENT EDWARDS REPLIED IN PART AS FOLLOWS:

The same applies here, as there is a strong current, and the outlet is some distance downstream from the water intake.

You may rest assured that the Department's first consideration is for the health of the people, and we don't consider there is any danger to health at any of the schools.

Before installation of the sewage disposal plant at schools is made, great care is taken that the health situation is being cared for.

Dear Sir:

We have been expecting your visit for the past month in connection with Indian cases here, and we hoped for the opportunity for you to see our water pump and take note of the repairs needed.

Knowing not if you are coming in the near future I take the liberty to ask you to please authorize the purchase of same for it is very urgent. It consist of one pair of connecting rod complete with crossheads and piston rods. As you know this pump is duplex. We have inspected same some time ago in order to make temporary repairs but the little thing is built solid and simply bored at the crosshead with no means of taking up any wear and especially one side is almost gone entirely, while the other one is not so bad.

The condition of the delivery pipe line do not permit any stop in order to keep it from freezing and if the worn connecting rod and crosshead should break before we can get repairs, serious consequences are almost sure to happen.

The approximate cost I presume will not exceed $25.00

Sincerely Yours,

[Signature]

Sir:

The Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the McIntosh Indian Residential School, has drawn attention to the cess pool. He states that this pool has a wooden cover, which is considered more or less dangerous, and the Principal has had a fence erected around the pool. The Inspector states that if a concrete cover were placed on this cess pool it could be covered with about 2' of earth and the appearance of the front of the school thereby improved. He states the lay brother at the school would do the work if the material required for the purpose is supplied by the Department.

I shall be pleased to have a report from you regarding this matter, stating the material required to cover the cess pool and the approximate cost of same, also if you would recommend that the work be done at the present time or left over until next Spring.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,

Dear Sir,

Replying to your letter 130-7-5 of 9th inst. re Concrete Cover for Cass pool at the McIntosh Residential School.

I visited the School on the 20th inst. and the cover required would be about 27' long by 10' wide and 9" thick according to Brother Eugene Gautier's measurements.

He had some difficulty in working out the material required, but figures it would cost in the neighbourhood of $300.00 owing to the difficulty in getting the material to the School.

He would require Cement, Lumber for the frame, Mesh, and extra strong twisted Steel bars as reinforcement, Gravel etc.

The work cannot be done at the present time as the Cass pool would have to be emptied and the only reasonable time to do this would be when the Children were on vacation next July, and in this connection the School have no Pump to do this work and might have to rent one either from Winnipeg or Sioux Lookout.

This meets with the approval of the Principal and we would be pleased to have the authority for this to be done at that time, as it would no doubt improve the appearance of the School and be much less dangerous.

March 4th, 1932.

Dear Sir,

Under separate cover, I am mailing you a copy of the plans for the proposed addition to the McIntosh School. These plans call for two wings measuring each 30 X 60, of the same style of construction as the present building. We had in mind at first to propose that these two wings be made fireproof but we realize that the cost would be rather high and, in view of the fact that the present building is only of frame construction, we personally see no objection to adopting the same kind of construction for the two wings.

The matter of enlarging the McIntosh School was placed before you as late as 1929 by Archbishop Beliveau, of St. Boniface, and myself. If my memory serves me well, the Archbishop was very insistent at that time that the enlargement of the school be proceeded with immediately. While no definite promise to that effect was made by your Department, it was nevertheless felt by both Archbishop Beliveau and myself that the school would be enlarged as soon as conditions permitted it.

The school now accommodates 75 pupils but there are as many children in the territory served by the school who are not attending a school at all and who are, therefore, growing up in ignorance. It is with a view to bringing a remedy to this situation that we are now pressing for the needed enlargement of the school.

In view of the fact that your Department, owing to existing conditions, has deemed it necessary to considerably reduce its Estimates and also in view of the fact that the Church authorities are prepared to provide the necessary funds for the children who are not now attending school and who are, as mentioned above, in the territory served by the McIntosh School, we would be prepared to consider some form of cooperation with the Department whereby we could proceed immediately with the proposed additions to the school.

From the information given to us by Bro. Gauthier, we estimate that the proposed wings would cost about $50,000, - $25,000 of which would be for materials and the balance for wages. If your Department were prepared to assume the payment for the materials, the Church authorities would finance the wages on condition that the amount so spent be refunded within, say, a period of four years, at the rate of 2½% in April, 1932, and the balance at the rate of 2½% per annum until fully paid, the full amount not to bear interest.

In view of the fact that we consider the enlargement of the McIntosh School urgent and also in view of the fact that the Church authorities are prepared to cooperate to the extent mentioned above, we hope that your Department will favourably consider our request.

Thanking you for the sympathetic consideration you will give this problem, we remain,

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Dear Sir:

At several occasions, we were promised a FRIGIDAIRE for our School, but for one reason or another, it is yet to come. It would not be a luxury to have one but a great necessity as the log house we were using to keep the ice in, is going into ruin even after the many and one reparations made to it.

With the heat we are having now constantly, there is no food that can be kept palatable without a cold room. It is a very hard and not a mere trifle besides a great expense to have meat or other food sent to us every week from Winnipeg. You may well think that during this hot weather meat does not keep more than a day or two ahead.

For this reason, I am pleading to the Department to provide us with a FRIGIDAIRE. Presently they are lower in cost as they were before and I can have it installed without expenses for labor. This summer, if a frigidaire is not granted an ice-house will be needed, but such house would cost more, counting lumber labor and installation of a cold-room.

I also would require a potato peeler. Presently we are having the little ones peel the potatoes, but although they are doing their best, enough cannot be peeled for the two principal meals each day. We have plenty of good potatoes and would like to give some to the children, but we are having much difficulty in getting them ready. No matter we would have a machine, some would be peeled by hands every day to teach the girls how to do them.

Thanking you for the present and past favors and hoping my requests be granted.

I remain

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Mr. A.F. MacKinnie, Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

A few days ago our night watchman has left our school for the reason he hasn't enough sleep during the day. We have tried several rooms in the school building, but anyone furnishes enough tranquillity to permit anyone to rest. We are so narrow of space, I do not know what to do, unless we have a building made for the night watchman.

It is the fourth one that leaves for this sole reason and this is the favor I am asking you today? To give me authorization to build a small building at proximity of the school. Two Hundred Fifty dollars ($250.00) would be sufficient provided the brothers make this little construction, which they are willing to do.

Please take this matter into consideration and reply at your earliest convenience.

Thanking you in advance, I remain,

Yours ever obliged,

C. Perreault
Principal.

Your obedient servant,

General Superintendent of Indian Affairs,

Dear Sir:

The following is a list of the requirements (for 1933-34) for the Indian Schools under our jurisdiction.

McIntosh School

1- This School has no root cellar and although one has been promised for several years past nothing so far has been done. A sum of $600.00 would be sufficient for this purpose.

2- The School is situated about 2½ miles by water from the railroad station and materials and supplies have to be freighted on a barge. Dear Sir:

On October the 19th we have received the circular addressed to all schools concerning the Fire Extinguishers, whether they were refilled and if they were in good order.

I have replied immediately on Oct. 27th saying our Fire Extinguishers were refilled in August but the Fire-guns nine out of ten were not working, some are clogged and others were leaking, and the brother didn't know what is to be done with them; he has tried to repair one but has spoiled it.

At the same time, I have advised the Indian Agent that the hearth and smoke drums of the bakery ovens were ruined, if you remember, the brother was trying to make a repair to it when you came for a visit last September but it could be only a temporary repair. Secondly, I notified the Indian Agent that the furnace doors and frames were broken, could not be repaired therefore needed to be replaced.

I am enclosing the Indian Agent's reply to my letter dated Oct. 27th, see copy A, then my reply, see copy B.

A week or so after, I have received the letter from Dept., see copy C; four days after this one, another one from Indian Agent, copy D; then the last, three days ago, the one marked E.

What correspondence! Eight letters just to have doors and frame of a furnace replaced, the hearth and drum of an oven replaced also and 5 fire guns to be repaired. It shows once more that when any items have to go through Mr. Edwards we must have plenty of time ahead of us and an enormous sum of patience.

Consequently I repeat what I have said for better understanding and for your information.

Nine fire-guns are not working, brother has tried to repair them but without success. So we cannot tell whether they can be repaired or not as the brother don't know what is to be done with them. Lately again, after receiving Mr. Mackenzie's letter and to accede to Mr. Mackenzie's desire, brother has worked on two fire-guns but to his dismay he has ruined them.
Secondly, the frame and doors of the furnace are broken and need to be replaced. The doors have been repaired a long time ago even without receiving notice from Mr. Mackenzie but the frame cannot be repaired. How can we tell what it will cost? The manufacture itself is more liable to tell this, we haven't got the price of the furnace or any of the pieces. It was purchased by the Department, and all invoices and bills were kept by the Dept. It is the same thing for the bakery oven. The hearth and drums are entirely burnt and have been repaired temporarily with pieces of iron and mud plaster but this cannot stand many more bakings. We cannot tell what it will cost to have new ones for the Dept., has purchased this oven and of course must have the invoices of each.

What I am sure of is this, we need a new frame for the furnace as it is dangerous for fire, the doors are just held closed by an iron bar, as for the doors they may do like this for quite a while unless they meet with another accident; and we need also a new hearth and smoke drums for the bakery oven.

When we have these new pieces, the brothers can attend to the work themselves without making extra expenses for outside labour.

I understand well that times are hard and it is difficult to meet with extra expenses, but we cannot see ahead what accident we are liable to have or how long things may last without being worn out, but these three items need prompt attention and we cannot do otherwise as claiming them. We are doing our utmost best to keep all expenses to its lowest point, and I may say also that all the repairs that we can do we are doing them in time enough so as to save money and time.

I regret to have been obliged to take up this matter so obliquely, but we get tired of repeating things over and over again.

Hoping to receive attention at your nearest future and thanking you in advance

I remain

Sincerely yours

Dear Dr. McGill,

You will recall that I personally interviewed you recently with reference to the necessity for a new chapel at the McIntosh Indian Residential School. I also had an opportunity of discussing this matter with the Honourable the Superintendent General yesterday. While I outlined our plan quite completely in these interviews, I believe that it is in the best interests of all parties concerned to place the matter before you in a formal manner.

The necessity of a new chapel for the McIntosh Indian Residential School has long been felt but, owing to economic conditions, the Principal has not previously urged the Department to appropriate funds for this purpose. A former missionary of the Lake of the Woods district, who passed away recently, has left a bequest for Indian work to the Oblate Order and we are prepared to devote this money to the erection of a new chapel.

If you permit us to proceed with this work, it will be on the distinct understanding that the new wing in which the chapel will be situated will conform in every respect to the architecture of the school.

The Oblate Order further undertakes not to urge upon the Department any claim for compensation for the cost of this chapel.

As we desire to proceed with this work immediately, we would appreciate receiving a favourable reply to our request at the earliest possible date.

On behalf of the Reverend Oblate Fathers,

Yours very truly,

J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.
April 5th, 1935.

Dear Father Plourde,-

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, with reference to the necessity for a new chapel at the McIntosh Indian Residential School. I note that the Oblate Order is prepared to erect this chapel at their own expense and that it will conform in every respect to the architecture of the present school.

It has been decided to favourably consider the proposal made in your letter of the 2nd instant and the Oblate Order may proceed with the erection of the chapel.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Sir:

On my inspection trip to the Indian Residential School at Mo. Intosh on the 9th inst. I inspected the new addition to the school made at the expense of the Church. They have erected an addition on the north side which is 30' X 60' at a cost to them of about $7500:00.

The cost is very small considering the structure and the Principal asks if the Department will supply the following:
(1) 24 Return Line Valves for Radiators (Dunham Steam Traps) to enable the heat to circulate better. This would cost in the neighbourhood of $300:00 or $400:00.
(2) Paint for the amount of about $200:00
(3) Toilets etc. $200:00
(4) Repairs to plaster which is given way in the old building 400 yards at $1:00 $400:00
(5) Switch Board Ammeter $10:00 on account of new generator changed from 30 amp. to 150 amp. to take care of the extra lighting.
(6) Repairs to Main Sewer $75:00, old sewer getting blocked up and cement floor would have to be broken to repair.
(7) Refills for 5 2½ gal. Pomite Fire Extinguishers
(8) 1 ½ gal. Sandan Fire Extinguishers
(9) 3 1½" Hose complete with Valves and Nozzles

The new addition contains accommodation for 52 beds and the Principal has furnished a pump for the furnace to assist in heating the building.

I informed the Principal I would pass on his requests and would await your instructions,

Your obedient servant,
[Signature]
Indian Agent.

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

During the winter just gone, we have had great difficulty in keeping the power-house warm enough to prevent from freezing, for the reason that we were afraid of fire caused by the stove pipe, there being no chimney. In fact we had several fires and the last time it started we had a great deal of trouble to extinguish it. We would like to build a chimney this summer as this will be an only mean to prevent a disaster. A good chimney would not cost more than $100.00. I beg of you authorization to have this chimney made and ask the Department to be kind enough as to furnish us the means to do it.

Hoping my request receive consideration

Ottawa, May 14, 1936.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 10th instant, addressed to Mr. Sutherland, of this Department, requesting authority to incur an expenditure of $100 in the building of a chimney on the power house at the McIntosh Indian Residential School.

In this connection I would say that the only amount provided in our Appropriation for the current fiscal year for your school is $450, to build a barge for freighting purposes. It was necessary, when preparing our Estimates, to curtail all expenditure as far as possible; and we were only able to obtain the amount mentioned above to build a barge.

I should be pleased to have particulars from you, regarding how you would propose having the work in building the barge carried out. It would, no doubt, be necessary to have it built near the lake. If you could inform the Department concerning the quantity of lumber and other material that would be required, with the approximate cost, and also what labour would be necessary, in addition to that done by the staff of the school, you would then be advised where the material should be purchased. Please state, also, what power will be used in operating the barge. Will it be towed by boat or will it be necessary to install an engine in the barge?

When the Department receives full particulars as to the cost involved in constructing the barge, consideration can be given as to whether any funds would be available in erecting a chimney for the power house. A reply, giving the information requested, will be appreciated.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Dear Sir:

Have received your letter of May 14th, but for urgent reasons could not answer any sooner; please excuse me for the delay.

Re the building of a barge for freighting purposes we had made the demand of authorization to build same for three consecutive years but never had a word about it. Last Spring as our barge had become so rotten it came apart and we could not use it any more, so having had no word from the Department, we made a new one in June 1935 as we could not be without one at all.

If the appropriation for the current fiscal year for our School is $450.00, I would suggest it be taken to pay the expenses of the barge built last June and for which I am enclosing the accounts in triplicate. The Brother Eugene Gauthier who had just went unto an operation could not build it himself but he was the one who has overseen the construction. We engaged two competent laborers for the work.

Mr. Frank Edwards

Kenora, Ont.

Dear Sir:

To conform ourselves to the Department's wish, we are making a list of our estimates for the next fiscal year. It is extra work which amounts to very little as we have made this list since three consecutive years without obtaining anything hardly. Here they are in order of rank:

1er. Root cellar estimated at ............ $500.00
As we are enlarging our garden a little more every year we have no place to keep the vegetables palatable, which is absolutely necessary for the welfare of our children.

2er. Hayloft and Implement shed, estimated $500.00
Our present hayloft is so small that we can only put one car load of hay while the other four cars which is the quantity required for the winter have to remain outdoors at all the inclemency of the seasons. A shed could be made for our hay and aside of it a shelter for the implements and wagons.

3er. The enlargement of our Stable, est. $1200.00
It is much too small for the number of cows we have. There is danger for them to become T.B. as they are overcrowded. We could possibly get a few more milch cows if we had the locality for them. The children do need more milk.

4er. Clearing land ......................... $500.00

I do hope that you will make your utmost possible to obtain same from the Department and for which we are thanking in advance.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

I have just received a letter from the Indian Residential School, McIntosh, requesting that the Department supply them with the following equipment:

- 2 large Toboggans
- 12 Hockey Sticks
- 6 pr. Boots & Skates

It is pointed out in the letter that the school has already provided a certain amount of equipment, but they are still short the items mentioned above.

I might say that this equipment can be purchased for approximately $25, and as I have had very few requests from this school, I would like to recommend that the equipment be supplied. It is just as important for the children to have equipment for winter sports as for summer—in fact, more so because there is always the danger of the children remaining inside too much during the winter months. I trust funds are available and would appreciate having a reply as soon as possible.

Yours truly,

A. G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

Ottawa, December 30, 1936.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 23rd instant, with reference to the request that you have received from the McIntosh Indian Residential School for toboggans, hockey sticks and boots and skates.

The only athletic equipment that the Department supplies to Indian schools is footballs, playground balls, basket balls or volley balls. Owing to lack of funds, it is not possible to consider supplying equipment other than that just mentioned, and, therefore, the request of the Principal of the McIntosh School cannot receive favourable consideration.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

We have received a wire from the Principal of the Residential School at McIntosh informing us that the pump had broken down and could not be repaired and asking authority to purchase a new one. We wired for particulars and costs but they have replied that there was no number on name plate, and as this case was very urgent Brother Eugene had gone to Winnipeg to purchase a new pump.

Ottawa, June 15th, 1937.

Dear Father Perreault,-

I have your letter of the 8th instant, requesting eighteen (18) single desks No. 2 for the McIntosh Indian Residential School.

In our appropriation for the current fiscal year, there was provided an amount of $500 for the construction of a root cellar at the McIntosh Residential School. Recently, Mr. Edwards wrote asking what amount we had provided for your school this year and he was informed that the amount mentioned in the previous sentence would be available. He was further instructed to consult you and advise whether or not the root cellar was to be constructed or if you preferred the money expended in some other manner. He has not yet replied.

The point to be kept in mind is that we can only provide $500 for repairs and replacements at the McIntosh School this year. If desks were supplied now, it would reduce the amount considerably.

I would, therefore, appreciate your advising if you really require the desks because, you will understand, the cost of them will have to be taken from the amount provided for the McIntosh School for the current year.

Yours truly,

Rev. C. Perreault, O.M.I.,
Indian Residential School,
McIntosh, Ont.

Philip Phelan,

July 9th, 1937.

Dear Sir,

With reference to your letter of April 16th regarding the condition of the dam at the McIntosh Indian Residential School, the matter was referred to the Surveys and Engineering Branch and they estimate that an amount of approximately $1,000.00 will be required to place this dam in good condition.

As it is important that these repairs be made at once, this Branch is authorizing the Surveys and Engineering Branch to proceed with the necessary work at the earliest possible date. As you have previously been informed, only $500.00 was provided in our current year's appropriation for repairs and improvements at the McIntosh School. The remaining $500.00 required for repairs to the dam is being taken from a small unlisted amount in our appropriation. Under these circumstances, no funds for other repairs and improvements can be allowed the McIntosh School during the current fiscal year. In this connection, I would refer you to official letter of June 1st, 1937. The amount mentioned in that letter is now required for repairs to the dam.

Yours truly,

My dear Mr. Phelan:

The McIntosh Indian Residential School is 175 miles from nowhere and all repairs to the mechanical appliances and the water power machinery of the school is very expensive unless done by the school staff.

Brother Eug. Gauthier, generally residing at the School, can make all these repairs when given the necessary tools. He could have done a great deal more of the machinery repair work if he had had an electric welder. There is one for sale at the present time at 20% reduction by Leeder's Limited of Winnipeg. I am enclosing a description of the machine.

If you can see your way to purchasing it for the McIntosh school I think the Department will have made a good investment and one which will pay for itself within a very short time. The price shown on the invoice is net; the 20% having been deducted.

Dear Sir:

Further reference is made to my recent visit to the McIntosh Indian Residential School.

Reverend Father Perreault and staff gave me every possible assistance in carrying out my inspection of the school proper as well as the other buildings used in connection with the school.

From the outside, one of the first requirements indicated is paint for the main building. I was told that paint had been ordered and that the matter of artificial brick or asbestos siding was under consideration. The building should either be painted or have the siding put on. If not done soon, paint now on will be entirely wasted.

The fire appliances were carefully inspected and found to be in order - with the exception of three old type hand pump tanks which should be replaced with pyrene tank type extinguishers. The fire hose within the building is apparently in good condition but I recommended to the Principal that the hose be tested outside the building first opportunity in order to test for rot. It has been my experience that the rubber in the hose perishes after a number of years whether in use or not.

The girls dormitory on the top floor, East Wing, is somewhat crowded. The main exit in case of fire is down a wooden stairway at the outside end of the building. While the stairway is large enough to accommodate all the pupils under normal conditions I would like to see an additional
Fire escape installed in this wing to take care of a situation in the event of fire cutting off the escape by means of the stairway.

I was impressed with the apparent health and cleanliness of the pupils. They are all robust and happy. The physique and carriage of these children is remarkable. The manual training for both boys and girls is progressing very well.

There are several acres of new farm land cleared and some ready for cultivation this year. The stock is well kept and the stables will compare with any on modern farms.

No doubt the craftsmanship and ability of the Brothers Gauthier has been pointed out many times before. These men are apparently able to turn their hand to anything and the saving effected by their efforts over a period of years would be difficult to estimate.

On the whole I was very favourably impressed with the work being done by this institution.

In the late afternoon I had an hours meeting with the Councillors and several members of the Grassi Narrows Band. They had several complaints and requests, all of which will be attended to in due course.

Yours very truly,

Gifford Hartman,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
May 17, 1939.

August 29th,
1939.

Mr. Gifford Swartman, Indian Agent,
Department of Indian Affairs,
SIOUX LOOKOUT, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

We are enclosing, herewith, in quadruplicate, our account amounting to $41.00, covering inspections at Sioux Lookout and McIntosh Residential Schools. Kindly have cheque made out, as per letterhead of account, and forward to Toronto. Certificates will be issued in due course.

Last year, we wrote Capt. Frank Edwards regarding the vertical boiler used for laundry purposes at the McIntosh School. This boiler was really much too small for the work when it was first installed, and seeing that much more work is being applied right along, I would strongly advise that a larger boiler be installed replacing the present one.

The whole trouble with the boiler is in the height. The water gauge glass is only 3" long and, consequently, the boiler is either full of water or water very low, so, therefore, I would again advise that a boiler be installed, with increased capacity. I may suggest it would be quite an easy matter to increase the height of the present boiler to give it the required capacity, by adding another course which would mean longer tubes being fitted and would cost much less than a new boiler.

Yours very truly,

John M. Kelly.

DEPARTMENTAL INSPECTOR.

Dear Sir:

I am today in receipt of a letter from the Principal of the McIntosh Indian Res. School, Rev. Father C. Perreault, O.M.I., who informs me that although the sum of $1400.00 was appropriated for an addition to the school stable, no materials have yet been received for this purpose.

Once more I wish to call your attention to a situation which is becoming increasingly difficult to cope with on the part of the Principals. The months of July and August, when the children are away on their holidays, are certainly the best months of the year to proceed with repairs, alterations and additions to the schools and outside buildings. If materials for repairs and additions are supplied late in September the work involved is not only more difficult but it is a great deal more expensive.

The Principal has asked me to report this case to the Minister, but I prefer to take it up with you personally as the Minister surely has much more weighty problems to look after.

Hoping that you will give Father Perreault's request your immediate attention, I remain,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Dear Sir:

Re: Boiler for Laundry - McIntosh Indian Residential School

Reference is made to your 130-7-5 dated February 27, 1940 and previous correspondence concerning the boiler in use in the laundry at the McIntosh Indian Residential School.

During a recent visit to the school I examined the boiler and it was found to be in bad condition. Mr. John M. Kelly, Provincial Boiler Inspector, informed me last year that in his opinion would only be good for one more year.

It was suggested in Mr. Kelly's report of August 29, 1939 - copy of which was forwarded you with our letter of September 6th, file 144:7-M - that the boiler be re-built but owing to the gauge of the metal it is now considered that this would not be satisfactory since it is no doubt badly rusted and pitted inside and in a few years would require a complete replacement.

The Port Arthur Shipbuilding Company has quoted on a boiler suitable for the School's requirements as follows:

1 -- PASCOL 13 H.P. Vertical Boiler, 32" dia. x 86" high, 100# working pressure; furnace 27" dia. x 27" high. Boiler will have 55 - 2" dia. tubes 51" long and will be complete with grates and trimmings, including two injectors.

PRICE: $525.00 f.o.b. Port Arthur, Ontario, including 6% Sales Tax.

SHIPPING WEIGHT: About 2,400 lbs.

Please advise if authority may be obtained to purchase same.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find list of paint required for the McIntosh Indian Residential School. I was informed, when I was in Ottawa last, that if this list was forwarded immediately, you would place the order without any delay.

Rev. Father Perreault, the Principal, informs me that the last lot of paint which was supplied came from Kenora and he was far from satisfied with its quality. It is also probable that the price was higher than what it would have been if the order had been placed with a wholesale house in Winnipeg. Your Purchasing Agent in Ottawa should be advised, I believe, that much better prices can be secured from wholesale firms than from local retail stores such as exist in Kenora.

A great deal of this paint work can be done now by the school staff without any extra cost in wages. But if your Purchasing Agent takes as long to fill this order as he does to fill most orders that are placed with him, the paint will be delivered to the school at a time when the men have to do all the Spring work, and consequently other employees will have to be secured, meaning extra expense for the school.

Thanking you in anticipation, I remain,

Yours very truly,

McIntosh Indian Residential School  
McIntosh, Ont., November 23, 1941.

Mr. Gifford Swartman,  
Indian Agent,  
Sioux Lookout, Ont.

Dear Sir:

As you have seen during your recent visit to this school that our pneumatic water tank located in the root cellar is now defective owing to inside corrosion.

We have noticed a few months ago, that it was difficult to keep air in it, but now it is impossible. It is always full of water to the top - consequently, there is no water available to the building when the turbine is shut off - even for a few minutes, which is a great inconvenience.

As the tank is placed on cement saddles, tight against the walls in a corner and within 6" from the ceiling it is impossible to locate the leaks and repair them. The only remedy is to replace it.

The present tank, 48" x 16' has been placed where it is at the time of the construction of the power plant, in 1925 and the cement walls for the root cellar, built after its erection. So, it is impossible to remove it unless the roof is taken off.

As mentioned to you, the new tank needs not be as large as this because the water pump is in constant operation.

We would suggest a size 30" in dia. by 96" long would be quite large enough and can be taken in through the present doors. Same tank to be installed on the side because the head room under roof being only 6'6", is limited by windows in adjoining room in basement and heating plant room.

The tank should
The tank should be provided with 4 openings under side as follows: One 3" opening for connection to supply pipe from the pump, two (2) 2" openings, one for connection for delivery pipe to building and one to waste, also one 1" opening for water column.

On the top there should be one 1" opening to correspond with the 1" below for water column and pressure gauge, and one ¾" opening for air line from compressor. There should be one manhole on the end near water column.

You have noticed the amount of water on the floor caused by the leaks which, owing to moisture, is very bad for preserving our vegetables.

Will you please be kind enough to interest the Department in this matter and have the small tank purchased as soon as possible.

With anticipated thanks

Yours very truly,

C. Perreault, O.M.I.,
Principal.
Ottawa,

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle

Red McIntosh Indian Residential School

When Mr. Wallace was engaged in work at the school last season he submitted a report on the condition of some of the buildings and equipment and suggested certain repairs. This matter was dealt with in our memoranda of December 16th, 1941, January 5th, 1942 and January 28th, 1942.

After visiting the school on June 23rd and finding that none of these repairs have been effected, Mr. Gow states as follows:

"However, the Indian Affairs Branch should be urged to supply the water storage tank as specified, without delay. The leakages through the roof over the kitchen, pantry, heating plant and over the pressure tank and roof house is very annoying and the roofing should be replaced.

"There is a serious leakage from the laundry room into the boiler room on wash days that was drawn to my attention. It appears that it flows down outside of the main pipe from the floor drain and goes through the walls into the boiler room. I suggest that they should themselves overcome this annoyance by breaking up the concrete around the floor drain and seal with new cement work the junction between pipe and flooring."

This matter might be brought to the attention of the Indian Affairs Branch again, particularly regarding the items mentioned by Mr. Gow.

Respectfully submitted,

Chief Engineer.

Dear Sir:

Re: Roofing, McIntosh Indian Residential School.

This Branch is in receipt of a memorandum from the Chief Engineer, Surveys & Engineering Branch, in which he states:

"Brother Eugene Gauthier of the McIntosh Indian Residential School was in Mr. Cow's office this morning and brought up the question of who was to carry out the work of repairing the roof at the school, now that the material has been purchased for the job and has been delivered. It was explained to Brother Gauthier that this office had nothing to do with the purchase of materials and it has received no word as to who is supposed to carry out the placing of the new roofing. Brother Gauthier stated that insofar as the Principal of the school was concerned they had not agreed to do any work in connection with the replacement of the roof and that they were unable to carry out any part of this work. The school authorities are anxious that this roof repair work be carried out at the earliest possible date."

In the estimates of this year the sum of $700.00 was provided for supplies and repairs at the McIntosh School. At this date the sum of $750.00 has already been spent. In view of this fact it will be exceedingly difficult, if not impossible, for the Department to provide the amount of money necessary to defray the cost of the labour necessary to the roof of the building. It so happens that this year we have exceeded most of our appropriations with the result that there are no funds available for this or any other purpose. Would it be possible for you to secure from the Principal of this school an estimate of the

Mr. G. Swartman,
Indian Agent,
Sioux Lookout, Ont.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6220, file 472-5, part 6)
cost involved and the extent to which the school is prepared to assist in this matter? If the school finds itself unable or unwilling to bear part of the cost it is just possible that these repairs may have to be postponed until the next fiscal year.

Your immediate attention to this matter would be very much appreciated.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Dear Sir:

Reference is made to our Estimates for 1943-44 which were recently submitted to the Department. You will note at that time we did not outline details for repairs to Works and Buildings required for the McIntosh Indian Residential School. We are enclosing herewith detailed list of requirements. Unfortunately the Reverend Principal did not furnish us with estimated costs and it would require approximately two weeks for us to obtain the necessary figures, consequently we are forwarding the list as received.

It is noted that a new wooden flume is required for the power plant. The Reverend Principal states that the one now in use might be patched in order to make it last throughout the winter, providing he could obtain rubber patching material.

Yours very truly,

G. Swartman,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

Referring to Mr. Hoey's letter of October 2nd, File 130-7-5, with respect to repairs required for the roof of the laundry and boiler room at the McIntosh Indian Residential School, I have to advise that the necessary repairs have been attended to by the School Staff. The roof is now in first class shape, although it may require an additional four barrels of coal tar next summer to mix in with the gravel. Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6220, file 472-5, part 6)
During a recent visit to the McIntosh Indian Residential School the condition of the bake oven was brought to my attention. This piece of equipment is in very bad shape and I recommend that steps be taken to replace same as soon as one may be procured. The oven in present use is an Oxford Portable No. 72 C manufactured by the Gurney Company, Limited, size $3\frac{1}{2} \times 4\frac{1}{2}$ feet and built in three sections. The top and lower sections are now useless and the middle one is the only part serviceable.

I understand that it is necessary to bake three days each week and two bags of flour are used for each batch of bread. With only the one section of the oven, many hours and much labour are required for each day's baking. It is also quite probable that the centre section of the oven will not last much longer. A larger oven should be obtained if possible, as the bake room would accommodate one from 8 to 10 feet long.

While on the subject of the McIntosh school, I wish to report that the new penstock is now completed and in use. The workmen made a first class job. All that remains to be done now is to place a roof over the entire length of the penstock in order to protect it from the weather. It is estimated that this structure will last for another forty years.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

G. Swartman,
Indian Agent.

Reverend Sir:

I am in receipt of the attached account from the Canadian National Railways, covering the cost of transporting two cartons of clothing to the McIntosh School. This clothing was forwarded to your school by the R.C.A.F. Station at Toronto on the request of this Branch. As you understand, clothing for pupils attending Indian residential schools is provided by the school management from per capita grant, or other receipts, and as a consequence when the Department arranges for supplying any Indian residential school with discarded military clothing it is felt that, as this is supplied free of charge, the school concerned should pay the carrying charges. This means that the school secures the clothing at a very reasonable cost. In view of what has just been said I feel certain that you will forward a cheque for $16.85 to the Canadian National Railways, Toronto, Ontario. Re: Estimates for 1944-5

1. Our scow that was built 20 years ago is absolutely gone; the wood is all rotten and cannot be repaired. A new one is urgent for next spring. The cost for material will be around $350.00.

2. The main drive belt for the turbine is in use since 20 years, was repaired several times and we are afraid it brakes soon causing lots of damages. A new one is also urgent. The cost will be around $100.00.

3. 20 M shingles to cover the water pipe that was built last year. Cost around $200.00.

4. 105 bags of cement to make new saddles under the water pipe. Cost about $100.00.

5. Paint, varnish etc., for many repairs to school and other buildings. Cost about $150.00.

If possible we would like to have materials for scow this winter, so we will have time to make it for the spring.

As for the belt, it would be preferable to have it now in case we have to replace the old one.
Ottawa, September 13, 1944.

Dear Father Perrault:

The Reverend Father Plourde has left with me a summarized statement of certain repairs and equipment which appear to be more or less urgently required at the McIntosh Residential School.

In the estimates recently approved by Parliament, the sum of $500.00 was included for repairs at McIntosh. Of this amount, however, $158.01 has already been spent for the purchase of paint. In view of all the circumstances and our earnest desire to keep our residential schools in a reasonably good state of repair, I would be prepared to recommend an additional expenditure of $800.00 at your school during the present fiscal year. It would be appreciated, therefore, if you would summarize your most urgent needs, the cost of which should not exceed this amount, and send them forward to us, together with any recommendations you may care to make, at an early date. It has occurred to me that these repairs should be undertaken at the earliest possible date.

Yours sincerely,

R. A. Rosey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
