During my recent visit to the McIntosh Indian Residential School, the installation of the new bake-oven was brought to my attention. This oven is installed in a new addition to the basement 28' from the main chimney. The oven manufacturers advise that the length of pipe from the chimney should not be over 10'. In this case it is impossible to have a shorter length than 28' due to the location or the chimney and oven. They also recommend a 10' pipe whereas the new pipe was 7', and entered the same flue in the main stack or chimney as the steam boiler and laundry. The former arrangement was very unsatisfactory, as the flue was not large enough to take care of all (boiler, laundry and oven) at the same time.

The alternatives to put the oven in working condition are:

1. Build a chimney which would be high enough to clear the main building and large enough to withstand wind pressure. This would mean a chimney 55 - 60' high, and would require guy wires. The estimated cost for such a chimney would be from $300. to $350.

2. To have an iron stack, specially made, of proper size and height to clear the buildings. The main objections to a steel smoke stack are that unless it is properly insulated there is a great deal of condensation. In this case, where the oven is only used every second day, the condensation would be even greater than if the stack was in use continually. We are unable to submit an estimate of the cost to manufacture a stack of this description.

3. The third alternative would be to install a special induced draft system. This would mean a short piece of iron smoke pipe extending 6' above the roof with an induction draft fan. The Alpha Manufacturing Company of Winnipeg quote a price of $285.00 to supply all necessary equipment for this installation.

It is recommended that this equipment be provided, as we believe it would prove highly satisfactory as well as less costly, and would also eliminate an additional chimney or smoke stack on the West side of the School which would detract from the appearance of the building.
EX'D.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

At the time of my recent inspection trip to the McIntosh Indian Residential School, the necessity for replacing two belts in the Power Plant, was brought to my attention. These are described as follows:

1. The main belt from the turbine to the drive-shaft pulley; 52' long by 8" wide, double heavy-duty, of the best quality, is required. This delivers from 30 to 40 Horse Power. This belt operates continuously under moist conditions and is used in every part of the Plant. The present belt is badly worn toward the edges, which means about 50% or less of the belt surface is operating the pulley. It slips, under a heavy load and will not drive the generator to full capacity at present. There is also the danger of the belt slipping off the pulley, and if this happened during the night when the light was extinguished, considerable damage would be occasioned in a few seconds, as the belt runs alongside a very intricate and expensive machine. It would also mean that the Power Plant would be out of operation, and the School would be without lights and water except that which could be delivered by the auxiliary gasoline motor.

The present belt has been in operation continuously for nineteen years.

2. Generator belt; A 28' by 6" double leather heavy-duty belt is required for the generator. The belt in present use has been in operation for ten years. It is badly cracked and in one place broken where something on the way across, beyond repair. If this belt is supplied, it is requested that it be joined or glued at the School. The belt is used on the 15 Kilowatt generator. It is important that a replacement for this belt should be supplied at a very early date.

Dear Sir:

Reply to your letter of Jan. 13th. File 144-7M

As requested, here is the explanation of the difference in price given by the Alpha Manufacturing Co.

The former plan furnished by one of the Company who was not an engineer and it comprised only one fan which had to be placed in the course of the pipe near the oven and through which the hot smoke or gas were to pass. This plan was not recommended by their engineer for the reason that such hot smoke would have burned the fan in a short time, and consequent heat transmitted to the pulley would have been very injurious to the belt. Same estimate comprised only the fan; piping was to be made here, whereas the last estimate included another type of fan outside of the smoke pipe, all the piping and the bracket to support motor and fan.

It is our wish that this Company should be favored with this order because, by their experience, they have really solved our problem in a way much cheaper than a brick chimney or steel stack.

If you think a copy of the Alpha quotation here included, will satisfy the Department. We would like to keep the original in the case the Department would refuse to supply it.

Yours very truly,

Re: New Bakery, McIntosh School.

The department has supplied a new bake oven for the McIntosh School and to install this oven it was necessary to enlarge the room used as a bakery. This addition measures 14'x14' and is 12' high. It is built entirely of cement and will later inside be lathed and plastered.

The chimney used before is now too far away and cannot be used. A new chimney would need to be 50' high and as only a 10" flue is required such a chimney standing by itself could not withstand the wind. The original chimney, which is used for the furnace, is 4" square at the base and over 50' high. A suitable brick chimney would involve a heavy expense. The alternative proposal is to build a low chimney and use the inductive draft method. The draft of the chimney is increased by use of a fan operated by a motor. The complete unit is manufactured by the Alpha Manufacturing Company, of Winnipeg, and Brother Gauthier states the price to be $325.00.

The installation of the oven is about completed and I recommend that the principal be authorized to purchase the inductive draft unit outlined above. I doubt if the cost would exceed the price of a large brick chimney, and Brother Gauthier states he is confident the system will give better results.

This matter should be authorized at once so the equipment can be obtained and the bills submitted prior to the first of March.

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies
for Manitoba.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Re: Belting Required at McIntosh School.

I understand this matter has already been submitted for approval. Two belts are needed.

1. The belt now in use on the second dynamo is no longer safe. It is badly checked with several cracks through the leather and part way across the belt. The belt required is a "Neptune" - 6" wide and 21' long, heavy duty, endless and is manufactured by Canadian Graton and Knight Ltd., 84 St. Antoine Street, Montreal.

2. The other belt is the main driving belt from the turbine to the line shaft. It is 8" wide and 40' long (one long piece the two ends of which can be laced on arrival). If rubber belting is supplied it should be not less than 10 ply - if leather, the same quality as that outlined above. The present belt is 20 years old and has had continuous service except for slight wear. The edge (both sides) is worn thin back 1/2" and so the driving power is reduced by 2½ inches. The belt locking surface power is inclined to slip; then when it takes hold of the load it tends to run off the pulley. If this belt should run off (and it is doing 24-hour duty) a serious breakage to the turbine might occur and the school would be left without light or water and it would necessitate closing down. I recommend that these belts be purchased at once, and thus eliminate the possibility of breakage.

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Affairs for Manitoba.

Schools:

During the quarter visits were made to both the McIntosh and Sioux Lookout Indian Residential Schools. At McIntosh an attempt was made to have the children familiarize themselves with the outside pole-type fire escapes. The boys were very proficient but the girls, especially the younger ones, were unable to use the escape with any degree of confidence. However, the Reverend Principal assured me he would see to it that they had plenty of practice in future. I might add that under certain conditions in the winter months, the iron pole fire escapes are dangerous for the inexperienced.

At the Sioux Lookout School the poles are inside the building. This arrangement permits the pupils to have more practice, although the efficiency of the arrangement is open to question. At the Sioux Lookout School twenty-two of the older pupils are enrolled in the Air Cadets. They are being trained by Miss Richardson, a staff member who was previously in the Women's Division of the R.C.A.F. These boys are all greatly interested in this movement and look very smart in their uniforms.

At both Residential Schools in this Agency lack of recreational and athletic opportunities is very noticeable. I believe that much more thought should be given to this phase of school life, as the Indian children seem to enjoy sports and games even more than our own children do. Under proper supervision this would go a long way toward developing character and physique.

G. Swartman,

AGENT'S REPORT FOR THE QUARTER ENDING DECEMBER 31ST 1945.

Welfare and Training.

Both the McIntosh and Sioux Lookout Residential Schools are practically filled to capacity. McIntosh has an enrollment of 131 and Sioux Lookout 150. The new road to the Sioux Lookout School was completed in early December, to the stage where it is passable. Owing to the lack of proper equipment to keep the road open it has not been of much value in recent weeks. Considerable graveling and widening will have to be done in the summer before it may be considered as an all-weather road. Some of the work could be done by the school staff if they had a dump-truck, and it is urged that one be provided. It could also be used to haul wood and would lessen the work of the pupils.

I have come to the conclusion that the children in our Residential Schools do not have sufficient recreation and opportunity to engage in sports and games. Actually they have not much time for such, owing to the endless chores and outside work. At the Pelican School, fuelwood in the winter months is one of the big problems—cutting it in the woods, hauling it to the School, sawing it and firing the boilers. It has been suggested to the Principal that he investigate the cost of coal as compared with wood. It certainly would be a tremendous saving in man or boy hours.

I am also of the opinion that the more labour saving devices that could be installed in our Schools, the better, as it would certainly allow the children much more time for other worthwhile activities. (It might be pointed out again that there is an extension of the hydro system to within two miles of the Sioux Lookout School.) However, like any other institution or business, the success of a School depends largely on management and supervision.

G. Swartman,
Indian Agent.

Mr. Philip Phelan, Chief Training Service,

Dear Sir,

The Plaunt Hardware Co are sending me their bills for an Outboard Motor that we used all Summer. I regret that as a new Principal here I am unaware that this motor has been forwarded as the result of a mistake on the part of the Company.

It appears that the Staff members were under the impression that the second motor had been sent by a tourist, who had promised to provide same free of charge. The thought in this matter was strengthened by the fact that the account covering the cost of the second motor only reached us later on.

Whilst we only asked for only one motor last spring, to save expenses to the Department, we really required two for the use of the School. You know that we are three miles from the Station and all our freighting and other trips to the station have to be made by boat. Furthermore, we need an outboard motor for recruiting purposes, as many of our children can only be reached by water over fairly long distances.

We have found these motors of great advantage. As they will be used in the future for the welfare of the School children, we hope that the Department will pay for both of them.

Yours very truly,

Rev. C.M. Comeau O.M.I.
Principal.

"The Plaunt Hardware Co. are sending me their bills for an Outboard Motor that we used all Summer. I regret that as a new principal here, I was unaware that this motor has been forwarded as the result of a mistake on the part of the Company.

Furthermore, we need an outboard motor for recruiting purposes, as many of our children can only be reached by water over fairly long distances.

We have found these motors of great advantage. As they will be used in the future for the welfare of the School children, we hope that the Department will pay for both of them."

Enclosed herewith is an opportunity offer of a stationary Air Compressor Unit, from a very reliable firm. Our engineer has examined it thoroughly and found it in first class condition at a bargain price.

It is further intended to serve the purpose of our old homemade water tank compressor which is now insufficient and would otherwise need to be renewed.

We beg that you kindly take notice of this special offer and promptly recommend the purchasing of above equipment to the Department before the end of the fiscal year.

Yours very sincerely,

Oct. 6th, 1947.

Mr. G. Swartman, Indian Agent,
Sioux-Loekout, Ont.

Dear Sir,

On the occasion of your last visit to the School, Dr. Bell pointed out that the cause of the high rate of sickness amongst our girls was the unfitness of the basement class rooms. These rooms are cold and damp. The sun rays never penetrate into them. And to add to this all, at the epoch of heavy rains, water infiltrates into the school, through the concrete foundations at the North west corner of one of the classrooms. The girls have to sit for hours in this chilly atmosphere, their feet on the concrete floor.

We have on the second floor, a space suitable for two class rooms. It is on the actual play-room of the girls. Over there it is warm and comfortable. There is plenty of sun-light. In every respect, more suitable than downstairs.

This place is also used as a reception room, at the occasion of Christmas entertainments and on other occasions. The stage could be transported down, and rebuilt exactly at the same place, because the two floors have identical dimensions. This will eliminate the inconvenience caused by the infiltration of water, leaving a space between the two floors.

This cannot be done without expenses. It will take lumber for two partitions between classroom, leaving space for a corridor between. Downstairs, in the new play-room, it will take three water closets and six wash basins. And also lumber for lavatory room.

It will therefore require about 2000 feet of quality lumber, which will amount delivered here, to about $200.00. Let us say, about $150.00 for the water works, and $150.00 for labor. Total amount $500.00.

As this is in the interest of the Department who have to spend so much money for the health of the Indians children, I do not hesitate to make this requisition of $500.00 in order to be able to proceed in making this necessary transformation, without delay. With the hope that you will be successful, I remain.

Yours truly:

C.E. Comeau O.M.I. Principal.
Sioux Lookout, Ontario,
October 7th, 1947.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Enclosed herewith please find memo from Rev. Father Comeau, Principal of the McIntosh Indian Residential School, with respect to changing the basement classroom to the upstairs recreation room, and having the recreation room in the basement.

Doctor Ball recommended this move in his June monthly report. In discussing the matter again yesterday with him he strongly urges that this be attended to without further delay, as he feels it is actually detrimental to the health of the children to be confined to the basement classroom.

Will you please advise as soon as possible if a grant of $500 will be allowed for the purposes mentioned, in order that the work may be completed before the cold weather sets in.

Enc.
Ottawa, October 10, 1947.

Mr. G. Smartman, Indian Agent,
Sioux Lookout, Ontario.

In view of the information contained in your letter of the 7th instant and the Principal's letter of October 6, the Department approves an expenditure not exceeding $500.00 in order to change the classroom and recreation room at the McIntosh Indian Residential School, as outlined in the communications above.

Bernard E. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

Attention: Mr. James Sinton,
McIntosh Indian Residential School,
McIntosh, Ontario.

It is understood that you recently discussed with our Superintendent of Education, the possibility of having a road constructed to the above noted school.

There are two alternatives for the construction of a suitable link between this school and the existing road:

(1) From McIntosh School via McIntosh Station to connect with the road constructed last summer by the Ontario Minnesota Pulp and Paper Company for winter hauling. This has been marked one on the attached sketch plan.

(2) The road from McIntosh into the school via McIntosh Railway Station to connect with the road from Alexandria Bay and Vermilion Bay. This has been marked two on the attached diagram. It is understood that there was a road location survey made of this proposed road in 1935. Unfortunately, this latter course requires twelve miles of road and would be a very expensive proposition.

Therefore, we requested Mr. G. Smartman, our Superintendent of Sioux Lookout Agency to discuss the situation with Mr. Kelly, your District Engineer at Kenora. We were advised that this official requested our assurance that the Department would share in the expense for the construction of the road outlined in bracket one above.
Mr. G. Swartman also took this matter up with the officials of the Ontario Minnesota Pulp and Paper Company at Kenora. Mr. Swartman advised that the road which they built last Summer from Quibell to the east end of the Lake near McIntosh, is a good one and that he feels that the Company would allow us to use it.

It would be appreciated if you could advise us as to the possibility of sharing the construction of the road from the McIntosh Indian Residential School to connect with the Ontario Minnesota Pulp and Paper road as described in bracket one above.

Yours sincerely,

I wish to acknowledge Colonel Neary's letter of December 15, File 472-5, with correspondence attached referring to the McIntosh Indian School road.

Referring to the proposed reply to Mr. Lew of the Ontario-Minnesota Pulp and Paper Company, I am in accord with the alternative suggested by Mr. Mattice, however, it should be borne in mind that we are using a good many miles of road constructed by the O & M and I believe it might pay to be a little more conciliatory. It is my suggestion to submit a proposal such as extending the road along the south side of the C.N.R. track approximately two hundred yards eastward and having a new crossing installed there at some future date or when the present crossing and right-of-way is found to interfere with their operations. The extension of the road eastward paralleling a right-of-way should not be an expensive proposition as there is no rock to contend with. There is, of course, the possibility that we may never have to do this as there should be ample space for piling. The crossing is over the main line west of the switch, consequently, it would hardly seem logical that the company would pile wood except along the spur where it could be readily loaded into cars.

I believe that if our crossing did actually interfere with the piling ground we could have the O & M with their equipment extend the road south of the track to point at the east end of their piling ground at very little cost to the Department.

[Signature]
Superintendent
Sioux Lookout Agency

CORRECT TEMPERATURE
The outstanding success of General Electric "Conditioned Air" Refrigeration may be attributed in a large measure to the exhaustive study of foods, their structure, and the reasons for spoilage, which was conducted by the Company. It was relatively easy to determine the correct temperature to halt bacterial and enzyme growth in various fresh foods. But this alone was not enough.

CORRECT HUMIDITY
With ordinary refrigeration systems, even though the correct temperature is maintained, perishables are found to lose a portion of their water content through dehydration, resulting in shrinkage and discoloration. Shrinkage in meats, for example, can under certain circumstances amount to 50 per cent of the original weight — a serious product loss. Refrigeration equipment for perishables must therefore also maintain the correct humidity conditions to keep shrinkage down to a minimum. It was also found that too much moisture in the air was liable to freeze-dried perishables to become slimy and to give off or pick up objectionable odors. Further tests established that the correct value varied between 70 and 90 per cent relative humidity, depending on the products stored and the length of storage.

POSITIVE AIR CIRCULATION
In addition to correct temperature and humidity conditions, ideal food preservation requires positive, gentle circulation of air through the entire refrigerated space in order to maintain uniform conditions throughout the area, without dead spots, or objectionable air blast.

AIR PURIFICATION—FASTER COOLING—SPACE SAVING
General Electric "Conditioned Air" Unit Coolers, the first of the kind in the refrigeration field, provide this essential balanced combination of humidity, air circulation, and temperature to maintain the quality, appearance, and weight of perishable foods. They can be adapted to correct conditions for almost any variety of foods and types of storage. Selecting a unit on the basis of a 16 degree difference between entering air and refrigerant evaporating temperature will provide a relative humidity of from 80 to 85 per cent, which is satisfactory in the great majority of applications. A smaller temperature difference will produce a higher relative humidity and, conversely, a larger difference will result in a lower relative humidity.

The very nature of the system provides added benefits. As the air in the space is circulated, it passes over the moist cooling surfaces. The moisture absorbs odors and particles of dust and dirt, keeping the air fresh and clean. The positive air circulation also makes possible faster cooling. Thus all foods placed in the refrigerated space are brought down to the correct temperature quickly and uniformly. And finally, the highest cooling efficiency of G-E "Conditioned Air" Unit Coolers makes possible an extremely compact unit, saving valuable cooler space.

SPECIFICATIONS

CASE
All-steel construction consists of top, bottom and sides in one piece with one-piece end covers all held in place by through bolts. Rubber buffers make a tight seal to protect against any possible rattle. Case is bonderized and finished in a baked-on brown enamel. Highly resistant to corrosion. Streamlined air intake orifice avoids air noise and permits most efficient fan operation.

COOLING COIL
Vertical rows of tubes with continuous bonded fins connected in series to drier coil at air inlet end, and expansion valve at air outlet end, provide counterflow refrigerant and air circuits. Tin-plated copper tubing, silver soldered joints and aluminum fins feature the cooling unit core. Fins are spaced six per inch.

FAN
Aphonic type—a product of the General Electric "House of Magic"—more efficient and quieter than ordinary fans, moves correct amount of air to give uniform temperature throughout the fixture with fast cooling.

DRYER COIL
Ample sized coil wrapped around and part of fan guard affords a means of preventing suction line sweating. It is located directly in path of intake air for greatest effectiveness.

MOTOR
Totally enclosed drip and splash-proof motor with pressure cast aluminum rotor winding. No brushes to wear, or to cause radio interference. High oil capacity, long life, trouble-free bearings need oiling only once a year. Only one size of motor used on all five cooling units. All 50- and 60-cycle and D-c motors are suitable for variable speed operation. Only one size of controller for A-c.

REFRIGERANT CONTROL
Thermostatic expansion valve included with unit. All connections are outside of case for ready accessibility.

Dear Mr. Neary:

We have received your wire approving purchase of the condensing unit.

The price mentioned covers cost of the equipment and complete installation of same.

For your information we would advise that we are dealing here with a walk-in cooler and the refrigerating equipment consists of a cooling unit inside the refrigerator and a condensing unit to operate same. When originally investigated in 1948 this equipment which is sulphur dioxide equipment required replacement of the cooling unit inside the refrigerator, which was unsatisfactory, and a new electric motor to be placed on the condensing unit. On arrival at this job our installing mechanic discovered that this SO2 condensing unit was now in extremely bad shape and the installation of the new coil and motor would be a waste because the result would not be satisfactory.

It was therefore determined that a new condensing unit be installed and this would mean that the whole equipment is being replaced with a new 1950 freon 12 installation. This is the proper step and will give satisfaction and the proper length of life to be expected from a completely new and satisfactory job. The additional equipment being supplied is one GWC31T, 1/2 HP General Electric freon water cooled condensing unit complete with 110 volt DC motor. The extra cost over and above the amount of the original order is $411.00. The new condensing unit is being shipped today and we will follow it up and have it installed immediately.

Thanking you,

Yours very truly,

Re your File 144/15-1472:
Fleming-Pedlar account $ 551.00.

Dear Sir,

In answer to your letter of the 2nd inst., regarding the second account of Fleming-Pedlar Ltd. to the amount of $ 551.00 I wish to say that it is regrettable that the account is not explicit enough and that it brought confusion to the point of refusal of payment.

The first item in the account concerns one CW331T ½ H.P. General Electric frozen water cooled Condensing Unit complete with 110 volt D.C. Motor, amount $ 411.00, which was authorized by Mr. Fleming as I see in a copy of the Company's letter giving to Mr. Henry on February 17th, 1950, complete explanation about the urgent necessity of replacing the old condensing unit, which was found not only defective but no more usable.

The second item concerns the 6 cu. ft. Refrigerator which should have been traded in with the coil and being kept by the school adds an amount of $ 140.00.

Here is the trade in allowance offered by the Company on Nov. 4, 1948: "We would be pleased to make you a trade in allowance of $ 150.50 on your present coil and the 6 cubic foot refrigerator. The used ½ H.P. electric motor you could keep and use elsewhere on the premises."

It was assumed then that the little refrigerator as well as the coil belonged to the Department, which fact is not right. It was likely thought also that it was useless whereas it could be serviceable with future repairs. The cook insisted on keeping the old small refrigerator owing to the fact that there is no reach in door on the large refrigerator and that the small refrigerator had always been so handy for many small items.

At the occasion of your visit here on March 1st, I showed you the small refrigerator asking you to inform the Department of its usefulness and of our wish to keep it. You said you would write the Department about it.

I would be very surprised that the Department would refuse to pay the small amount of trade in balance when the circumstances are duly known about this small school refrigerator.

Hoping this explains thoroughly the account, I remain, dear Sir,

Sincerely yours,

Rev. J. Brachet, O.M.I.,
Principal.

We are enclosing a copy of letter recently received from Father Brachet, Principal at the McIntosh Indian Residential School, with respect to condensing unit and 6 cubic ft. refrigerator which should have been turned in.

Apparently Father Brachet is under the impression that the purchase of the condensing unit with motor amounting to $411.00 was approved. As he points out, the old unit was certainly defective. The 6 cubic ft. refrigerator with motor should have been turned in in accordance with the Purchase Order but, since it can be used to good advantage at the school, it was retained. There also seemed to be some doubt in the Principal's mind as to whether the 6 cubic ft. refrigerator was the property of the school or Department.

I would suggest that, if at all possible, the Department assume the cost of the unit installed by the Fleming Pedlar Company and that the school be assessed for the trade-in value of the small refrigerator.

Dear Father Plourde:

Re: McIntosh Residential School

With reference to your letter of the 5th instant forwarding a copy of a letter received from Reverend Principal at the above school, the Department does not feel prepared at the present time to purchase a boat and an outboard motor.

On the insistence of the previous Principal, the Department has expended a considerable sum of money for the erection of a road and we feel that the School Management should not expect us to supply a boat also.

Yours sincerely,
